definition: A wave that breaks evenly on both sides, forming a peak in the center, resembling the shape of an ‘A’.
An Australian expression for aggressive surfing or aggressive surfer.
A wooden surfboard originally used by Hawaiians in the late 19th century.
A Hawaiian greeting that means “hello” or “goodbye”.
Excited or stoked before, during, or after a surf session.
When a surfer pulls into a hollow section from behind the section.
When a surfer rides with their back to the wave.
The water that flows back into the ocean after a wave breaks onshore, often disrupting incoming waves.
An evasive maneuver activated when a surfer is caught inside or when they are about to wipe out.
Letting go of your surfboard.
A sandbank.
The hollow part of a wave where a surfer can ride inside the curl of the wave, also known as the tube.
The measurement of water depths in oceans and seas.
Waves that break over sandbars.
Someone, usually a surfer, who hangs around the beach.
A bodyboard used to ride waves in a prone position.
A rough block of polyurethane foam that will be transformed into a surfboard.
The sport of riding waves using only the body and swim fins.
When a surfer’s weight is too far back, causing the surfboard’s nose to lift up.
A deepwater offshore reef break.
A bodyboarder.
When a surfer turns at the bottom of the wave to start trimming the optimal surf line.
Brother, mate.
To drop in on someone or steal a wave from another surfer without priority.
A sharp turn on the wave face.
When a surfer is too close to the beach in the impact zone.
Water falling at a barrel opening, threatening the tube rider.
When a surfer is giving it all and putting on a show – 'he’s charging!'
Bumpy ocean and wave conditions due to strong winds and/or currents.
When the ocean surface is rough and bumpy due to strong winds or cross swells.
A set of powerful waves that clears the lineup.
When a wave breaks all at once along its length, making it impossible to ride.
The vision of a series of swells marching in from the horizon.
The top and highest point of a wave.
A footwork technique that allows surfers to walk up and down the surfboard.
A turn performed on the flats or in the shoulder of the wave to get back to the power zone.
Surfing at sunrise to catch uncrowded waves and favorable conditions.
The top of the surfboard.
A crack, hole, or fracture in a surfboard.
The small exit hole a surfer uses to get out of the barrel.
The moment after paddling in and standing up, just before the first turn on the wave face.
To catch a wave that someone else is already riding, considered bad etiquette.
The technique of pushing the surfboard under and through a breaking wave.
A cool person, surfer, or skateboarder.
A type of plastic resin used to produce surfboards.
A technique used by surfers on longboards to roll under a breaking wave by flipping the board over and holding on tightly.
The uninterrupted distance over which the wind blows without a significant change in direction.
A hydrofoil mounted at the tail of a surfboard to improve directional stability and control through foot-steering.
Amazing and spectacular wave conditions.
When there are no surfable waves, and the ocean surface is calm.
The horizontal part of a breaking wave, also known as the shoulder.
Swim fins.
A surfing maneuver where the rider goes over the top of a crumbling section and ends up in the flats.
Whitewater.
A soft-top surfboard made of foam, ideal for beginners.
The block of foam from which a surfboard is shaped.
When a surfer rides facing the wave.
Stoked, amped, or excited.
A complete neoprene wetsuit.
A mid-length surfboard, also known as Malibu or minimal.
When the wind stops blowing, and the ocean becomes smooth and glassy, often occurring in the evening.
Perfect wave conditions with a smooth ocean surface.
An unbroken wave that is ideal for riding.
The sound of the fins or rail of the surfboard scraping along the wave face.
A longboard maneuver where the surfer walks to the nose and hangs all 10 toes off the edge.
A sharp turn on the wave face, often at high speed.
A wave that breaks in a barrel shape, creating a deep, steep hollow.
Performing difficult and stylish maneuvers on the wave.
Short for Indonesia, a popular surf destination known for its perfect waves.
The portion of the wave closest to the shore.
A surfer who is inexperienced or lacks skill, often used pejoratively.
The cord that attaches a surfboard to the surfer
Another term for leash
The spot in the ocean where surfers line up to catch waves, just behind the breaking zone
The curling part of a wave
Aggressive territorial protection of a surf spot by local surfers
Another word for longboard
The longest surfboard
The time between sets of waves with no waves breaking
Big
Crazy or radical
A slow and fat wave
A surf spot that breaks on a faraway reef
An ultra-stretchy rubber made from melted-down petroleum chips used to make wetsuits
Wind blowing from the shore out to the ocean, holding the curl line and smoothing the wave face
Wind blowing from the ocean toward shore, destroying the quality of waves
An Australian expression for paddling through the breaking waves into the line-up zone
The shape of a surfboard from nose to tail
The line-up area, as opposed to inside
A free fall from the top of a wave into the tumbling water cylinder
A race between surfers to get into a curl first and thus gain the right of way
A small bellyboard
A wave that is shared and enjoyed by several surfers at the same time
The spot in the ocean where the wave breaks for both sides
What happens when a surfer's weight is too far forward, and the surfboard nose dives underwater
A perfectly ridden wave in competitive surfing
The impact zone of the wave, or the most hollow part of the tube
Tubed, barreled
The most common type of material used in surfboard manufacturing
The quick move a surfer makes to rise to a standing position when taking off on a wave
The right of way rule in the surf
To perform an aerial maneuver
Personal watercraft; a generic term for a jet ski
The number/collection of surfboards owned by a surfer
The edge of a surfboard
A form-fitting shirt made of a nylon-polyester-spandex mixture used under the wetsuit
A wave that breaks over rock or coral
When a wave strikes a hard object and bounces some of its energy off into another direction
The effect by which a swell moving along a point of land slows down where it feels shallow water
A surfer who rides waves with his left foot forward
The priority given to the surfer closest to the breaking part of the wave
To surf very well
A strong surface current of short duration flowing seaward from the shore, also known as riptide
The curve of the surfboard bottom from nose to tail viewed from the side
An open ocean wave bigger than the current sea condition
A part of the wave that breaks ahead of the curl line
A group of waves
Another expression for getting barreled
A Hawaiian hand gesture used to say 'hello,' 'great,' 'cool,' and 'alright'
A surfboard designer and producer
The effect by which waves entering shallower water increase in height
The clean, unbroken, and rideable part of the wave
The area where the ocean waves meet the beach
A small surfboard
To aggressively ride a wave to the fullest
Impressive, amazing, crazy
To be cut by the surfboard fin upon wipeout
An old expression for surfboard fin
A heavy reef break coming out of deep water and breaking in very shallow water
The aggressive act of paddling under, around, or over the top of another surfer to get right of way
The broken foam of a wave
A surfing technique that allows a surfer to slow the speed of the surfboard to let the tube catch up
The surfer's feet position on a surfboard
A slang for surfboard
The wooden material that runs down the center of the surfboard to give strength and flexibility to the foam
Enthusiastic, exhilarated, or excited
Stand-up paddleboard
A wave that doesn't have time to break because the transition from deep water to shallow water is too fast
The energy powered by strong winds that produce wave trains
The start of a wave ride
The three-fin surfboard design created by Simon Anderson
A rare phenomenon in which the leading edge of the incoming tide forms a wave that travels up a river
When surfers use personal watercraft to tow into waves that can't be paddled into
Finding the perfect surf line for speed on the wave face
The bottom of the wave, the opposite of a crest
A giant and deadly wave
The hollow interior of a wave, also known as barrel
A surfing technique where the surfer flips the board over in front of an oncoming wave to get under it
A surfboard with two fins
A female surfer
The difference between the elevations of a crest and a neighboring trough
The time between two consecutive wave crests
A group of swells of similar wavelengths
The distance between the crest of one wave to the crest of the next wave
A paraffin-based product that is applied to the surfboard deck to increase traction and reduce slippery
A steep wave
A garment made of neoprene that provides thermal insulation
The foamy, white-colored water created where a wave breaks
A group of waves generated by local winds within less than 800 miles from the coast
